title.narrative: Mechanism 17177 - SANRU Clinical and PMTCT Scale-up

description.narrative:
Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
SANRU will be delivering PMTCT Option B+ services in 5 austere underserved health zones, Kalemie, Kiambi, Nyemba, Nyunzu and Moba (In Katanga Province) to a target population of 1 million. With the exception of Kalemie, none of these HZs are receiving HIV interventions. In Kalemie SANRU is funded by Global Fund for a limited number of sites. We will extend services to currently unengaged sites. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.8: Orphans and Vulnerable Children. Activities are aimed at improving the lives of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) affected by HIV/AIDS, and doing so in a measurable way. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.12: Laboratory Infrastructure. Development and strengthening of laboratory systems and facilities to support HIV/AIDSrelated activities including purchase of equipment and commodities and provision of quality assurance, staff training and other technical assistance. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.4: Biomedical Prevention - Injection Safety. Policies, training, waste-management systems, advocacy and other activities to promote medical injection safety, including distribution/supply chain, cost and appropriate disposal of injection equipment and other related equipment and supplies. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.13: Health System Strengthening. Include activities that contribute to national, regional or district level systems by supporting finance, leadership and governance (include broad policy reform efforts including stigma, gender, etc.), institutional capacity building, supply chain or procurement systems, Global Fund programs and donor coordination. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives

SANRU will be delivering PMTCT Option B+ services in 5 austere underserved health zones, Kalemie, Kiambi, Nyemba, Nyunzu and Moba (In Katanga Province) to a target population of 1 million. With the exception of Kalemie, none of these HZs are receiving HIV interventions. In Kalemie SANRU is funded by Global Fund for a limited number of sites. We will extend services to currently unengaged sites. Kalemie HZ is central to the other health zones and serves as a base for this project.
Limited data on HIV prevalence exists in these HZs. Risks, however, for higher prevalence includes economic activity and mobility in three health zones (Kalemie, Nyemba and Moba) which are along the lake. Also, rebel groups have been operating in all HZs recently.
During COP14, 25 sites will be added to 25 sites that we be made active around August 2014. The first new sites will function for 8 months while the previous sites will function for 12 months during COP14.
Efficiency will be ensured by collaborating with the Ministry of Health. As the project progresses, greater independence will ensured by allowing the Equip Cadre to assume responsibility. At the same time we will monitor and ensure consistent performance. MER indicators will be used to identify and improve performance.
SANRU has been a consistent partner with the MOH for decades. However, when the MOH decides to take over or move operations to another partner, SANRU will cooperate. HZ and site staff are already in the government system so the field aspect of the project would remain the same.
SANRU will follow the proscribed MER plan from PEPFAR. Additional M&E activities will be added as needed. The SNIS with supplemental data with provide data to be used for decision-making at all levels.

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.
